definition: the river flows thirty years to the East, thirty years to the West (proverb)/change is the only constant
pinyin: san1 shi2 nian2 he2 dong1 , san1 shi2 nian2 he2 xi1
traditional: 三十年河東，三十年河西
word: 三十年河东，三十年河西

definition: east/host (i.e. sitting on east side of guest)/landlord
the West/abbr. for Spain 西班牙[Xi1 ban1 ya2]/Spanish
see 風水輪流轉|风水轮流转[feng1 shui3 lun2 liu2 zhuan4]
No flower can bloom for a hundred days./Good times do not last long. (idiom)
the old man lost his mare, but it all turned out for the best (idiom); fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
pinyin: sai4 weng1 shi1 ma3 yan1 zhi1 fei1 fu2

definition: lit. the rear waves of the Yangtze River drive on those before (idiom)/fig. the new is constantly replacing the old/each new generation excels the previous/(of things) to be constantly evolving
pinyin: Chang2 Jiang1 hou4 lang4 tui1 qian2 lang4

definition: lit. that which is long divided must unify, and that which is long unified must divide (idiom, from 三國演義|三国演义[San1 guo2 Yan3 yi4])/fig. things are constantly changing
pinyin: fen1 jiu3 bi4 he2 , he2 jiu3 bi4 fen1

definition: if you live a life of crime, sooner or later you'll pay for it
pinyin: chu1 lai2 hun4 chi2 zao3 yao4 huan2 de5

definition: however strong you are, there is always someone stronger (idiom)/there is always sth more to learn/never be satisfied to rest on your laurels/there is no room for complacency
pinyin: qiang2 zhong1 zi4 you3 qiang2 zhong1 shou3

definition: a real man doesn't boast about his past achievements (idiom)
pinyin: hao3 han4 bu4 ti2 dang1 nian2 yong3

definition: lit. people fear getting famous like pigs fear fattening up (for the slaughter)/fig. fame has its price
pinyin: ren2 pa4 chu1 ming2 zhu1 pa4 zhuang4

definition: you can't judge a person by appearance, just as you can't measure the sea with a pint pot (idiom)
pinyin: ren2 bu4 ke3 mao4 xiang4 , hai3 shui3 bu4 ke3 dou3 liang2
related.word: 人不可貌相，海水不可斗量

definition: see 成則為王，敗則為寇|成则为王，败则为寇[cheng2 ze2 wei2 wang2 , bai4 ze2 wei2 kou4]

lit. even a scrawny camel is bigger than a horse (idiom)/fig. even after suffering a loss, a rich person is still better off than ordinary people/a cultured person may come down in the world, but he is still superior to the common people
pinyin: shou4 si3 de5 luo4 tuo5 bi3 ma3 da4
